rule.mdDesc: Forbid classes with name starting with Sonar

rules.name: Expressions should not be too complex
rules.htmlDesc:
The complexity of an expression is defined by the number of &&, || and condition ? ifTrue : ifFalse operators it contains. A single expression's complexity should not become too high to keep the code readable.

The following code, with a maximum complexity of 3:

if (condition1 && condition2 && condition3 && condition4) { /* ... */ }  // Non-Compliant

could be refactored into something like:

if (relevantMethodName1() && relevantMethodName2()) { /* ... */ }        // Compliant

/* ... */

private boolean relevantMethodName1() {
  return condition1 && condition2;
}

private boolean relevantMethodName2() {
  return condition3 && condition4;
}

descriptionSections.content:
Recommended Secure Coding Practices

  • activate Spring Security's CSRF protection.

Recommended Secure Coding Practices

params.desc: Maximum number of allowed conditional operators in an expression

rules.name: Avoid too complex class
rules.htmlDesc:
The Cyclomatic Complexity is measured by the number of (&&, ||) operators and (if, while, do, for, ?:, catch, switch, case, return, throw) statements in the body of a class plus one for each constructor, method (but not getter/setter), static initializer, or instance initializer in the class. The last return stament in method, if exists, is not taken into account.

Even when the Cyclomatic Complexity of a class is very high, this complexity might be well distributed among all methods. Nevertheless, most of the time, a very complex class is a class which breaks the Single Responsibility Principle and which should be re-factored to be split in several classes.

rules.name: Methods should not be too complex
rules.htmlDesc:
The Cyclomatic Complexity is measured by the number of (&&, ||) operators and (if, while, do, for, ?:, catch, switch, case, return, throw) statements in the body of a class plus one for each constructor, method (but not getter/setter), static initializer, or instance initializer in the class. The last return stament in method, if exists, is not taken into account.

Even when the Cyclomatic Complexity of a class is very high, this complexity might be well distributed among all methods. Nevertheless, most of the time, a very complex class is a class which breaks the Single Responsibility Principle and which should be re-factored to be split in several classes.

rules.name: XPath rule
rules.htmlDesc:
This rule allows to define some homemade Java rules with help of an XPath expression.

Issues are created depending on the return value of the XPath expression. If the XPath expression returns:

  • a single or list of AST nodes, then a line issue with the given message is created for each node
  • a boolean, then a file issue with the given message is created only if the boolean is true
  • anything else, no issue is created

Here is an example of an XPath expression to log an issue on each if statement : //ifStatement
rules.mdNote:
The tree produced by the firstOf() matcher is hard to work with from checks when alternatives are not named.

Consider the following rule: 

b.rule(COMPILATION_UNIT).is(
 b.firstOf( /* Non-Compliant */
 "FOO",
 "BAR"));

If, from a check, one wants to forbid the usage of the "BAR" alternative, the easiest option will be to verify that the value of the first token is "BAR", i.e. "BAR".equals(compilationUnitNode.getTokenValue()).

This is not maintainable, for at least two reasons:

  • The grammar might evolve to also accept "bar" in lowercase, which will break "BAR".equals(...)
  • The grammar might evolve to optionally accept "hello" before the firstOf(), which will break compilationUnitNode.getTokenValue()

Instead, it is much better to rewrite the grammar as: 

b.rule(COMPILATION_UNIT).is(
 firstOf( /* Compliant */
 FOO,
 BAR));
b.rule(FOO).is("FOO");
b.rule(BAR).is("BAR");

The same check which forbids "BAR" would be written as: compilationUnitNode.hasDirectChildren(BAR). This allows both of the previous grammar evolutions to be made without impacting the check at all.
rules.htmlNote:
<p>
The tree produced by the <code>firstOf()</code> matcher is hard to work with from checks when alternatives are not named.
</p>

<p>
Consider the following rule:
</p>

<pre>
b.rule(COMPILATION_UNIT).is(
b.firstOf( /* Non-Compliant */
"FOO",
"BAR"));
</pre>

<p>
If, from a check, one wants to forbid the usage of the "BAR" alternative,
the easiest option will be to verify that the value of the first token is "BAR",
i.e. <code>"BAR".equals(compilationUnitNode.getTokenValue())</code>.
</p>

<p>
This is not maintainable, for at least two reasons:
</p>

<ul>
<li>The grammar might evolve to also accept "bar" in lowercase, which will break <code>"BAR".equals(...)</code></li>
<li>The grammar might evolve to optionally accept "hello" before the <code>firstOf()</code>, which will break <code>compilationUnitNode.getTokenValue()</code></li>
</ul>

<p>
Instead, it is much better to rewrite the grammar as:
</p>

<pre>
b.rule(COMPILATION_UNIT).is(
firstOf( /* Compliant */
FOO,
BAR));
b.rule(FOO).is("FOO");
b.rule(BAR).is("BAR");
</pre>

<p>
The same check which forbids "BAR" would be written as: <code>compilationUnitNode.hasDirectChildren(BAR)</code>.
This allows both of the previous grammar evolutions to be made without impacting the check at all.
</p>

params.defaultValue: The XPath expression matches this piece of code

rules.name: firstOf() alternatives should be rules or token types
rules.htmlDesc:
The tree produced by the firstOf() matcher is hard to work with from checks when alternatives are not named.

Consider the following rule: 

b.rule(COMPILATION_UNIT).is(
 b.firstOf( /* Non-Compliant */
 "FOO",
 "BAR"));

If, from a check, one wants to forbid the usage of the "BAR" alternative, the easiest option will be to verify that the value of the first token is "BAR", i.e. "BAR".equals(compilationUnitNode.getTokenValue()).

This is not maintainable, for at least two reasons:

  • The grammar might evolve to also accept "bar" in lowercase, which will break "BAR".equals(...)
  • The grammar might evolve to optionally accept "hello" before the firstOf(), which will break compilationUnitNode.getTokenValue()

Instead, it is much better to rewrite the grammar as: 

b.rule(COMPILATION_UNIT).is(
 firstOf( /* Compliant */
 FOO,
 BAR));
b.rule(FOO).is("FOO");
b.rule(BAR).is("BAR");

The same check which forbids "BAR" would be written as: compilationUnitNode.hasDirectChildren(BAR). This allows both of the previous grammar evolutions to be made without impacting the check at all.

params.defaultValue: Refactor this firstOf() to only use a rule or token type for each alternative.

rule.name: Avoid too complex class
rule.htmlDesc:
The Cyclomatic Complexity is measured by the number of (&&, ||) operators and (if, while, do, for, ?:, catch, switch, case, return, throw) statements in the body of a class plus one for each constructor, method (but not getter/setter), static initializer, or instance initializer in the class. The last return stament in method, if exists, is not taken into account.

Even when the Cyclomatic Complexity of a class is very high, this complexity might be well distributed among all methods. Nevertheless, most of the time, a very complex class is a class which breaks the Single Responsibility Principle and which should be re-factored to be split in several classes.
